unnormalised: So, I was thinking about titles the other day, you know? Especially in the medical field. It's kinda a big deal, right? Like, you wouldn't just call any ol' person "Dr." now, would you? My cousin, Priya, she’s been working so hard to become Dr. Sharma.
normalised: So, I was thinking about titles the other day, you know? Especially in the medical field. It's kinda a big deal, right? Like, you wouldn't just call any old person "Doctor" now, would you? My cousin, Priya, she’s been working so hard to become Doctor Sharma.

unnormalised: It got me thinking about all the different titles out there. We've got your basic Dr. for starters. Then you have specialists like MD, which, correct me if I'm wrong, stands for Doctor of Medicine. And then there’s the whole world of consultants – like Senior Consultant, and Consultant Neurologist. It's a jungle out there!
normalised: It got me thinking about all the different titles out there. We've got your basic Doctor for starters. Then you have specialists like M-D, which, correct me if I'm wrong, stands for Doctor of Medicine. And then there’s the whole world of consultants – like Senior Consultant, and Consultant Neurologist. It's a jungle out there!

unnormalised: And what about the nursing staff? You've got RN, that's Registered Nurse, right? And then there's Nurse Practitioner (NP) and all sorts of other abbreviations and titles that I frankly get lost trying to keep straight. My bua, she's a Head Nurse at AIIMS, and even she needs to look some of them up sometimes!
normalised: And what about the nursing staff? You've got R-N, that's Registered Nurse, right? And then there's Nurse Practitioner (N-P) and all sorts of other abbreviations and titles that I frankly get lost trying to keep straight. My bua, she's a Head Nurse at A-I-I-M-S, and even she needs to look some of them up sometimes!

unnormalised: Then there are the academic titles. Like, Prof. Gupta who taught me biology in college! He was always so insistent on being called "Prof." It felt so formal, but I guess he earned it. And what about PhDs working in research? They might not be treating patients directly, but they're still contributing to the field.
normalised: Then there are the academic titles. Like, Professor Gupta who taught me biology in college! He was always so insistent on being called "Professor." It felt so formal, but I guess he earned it. And what about P-h-D-s working in research? They might not be treating patients directly, but they're still contributing to the field.

unnormalised: And don’t even get me started on all the different areas of specialization. You hear things like "Cardiologist," "Oncologist," "ENT specialist," and it's like, how does anyone keep track of it all? I once mistakenly asked an eye doctor about a skin rash! Talk about embarrassing.
normalised: And don’t even get me started on all the different areas of specialization. You hear things like "Cardiologist," "Oncologist," "E-N-T specialist," and it's like, how does anyone keep track of it all? I once mistakenly asked an eye doctor about a skin rash! Talk about embarrassing.

unnormalised: It’s interesting though, how much weight these titles carry, especially here in India. Like, people automatically assume you’re brilliant and know everything if you have "Dr." in front of your name. Which, of course, isn't always the case! But it's a cultural thing, you know?
normalised: It’s interesting though, how much weight these titles carry, especially here in India. Like, people automatically assume you’re brilliant and know everything if you have "Doctor" in front of your name. Which, of course, isn't always the case! But it's a cultural thing, you know?

unnormalised: Anyway, just some random musings about titles in the medical world. Maybe someone can create a handy guide to keep it all straight? I know I could use one. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go have a cup of chai. Ta-ta for now!
normalised: Anyway, just some random musings about titles in the medical world. Maybe someone can create a handy guide to keep it all straight? I know I could use one. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to go have a cup of chai. Ta-ta for now!
